Reviews.Title: A Very Competitive Underwater (and Land Use) Camera
Reviews.Author: Martin A Hogan "Marty From SF"
Reviews.Content: This Sealife camera and housing is sturdily built and easy to operate.  Just take some time to read all the directions!In the housing, the camera has two simple buttons on top; one for on/off and one to switch from photo mode to video mode. The Sealife 12 Megapixel 5X Optical Zoom and 3-Inch LCD screen Underwater/Land Camera is the brains of this operation, with an easy setup that allows you to set it to Underwater or Land. If Underwater, then choose Camera+Flash (for use with strobe) or Camera only. Then select Snorkeling or Diving. If Snorkeling, then select <25 feet or Diving select > 25 feet. You can also adjust the Diving strobe for External Flash Auto or Manual mode. There are also detail settings for green or blue water and at < or > 25 feet. These are your automatic white balance settings. The camera also has a unique `spy mode' where you can set the camera on a small tripod or steady surface and set the timer interval in order to capture that elusive sea creature. There is a function to record a subject onto an existing background image, combing shots of two people into a single image and a setting for a Panorama Mode! The latter uses a program called Arcsoft Panorama Maker 4.0 to allow you to stitch a panoramic photo together!The shutter button is meant to be pressed halfway until a green square appears, assuring you that the picture is in focus. Full shutter pressing takes the picture. The camera really is set up just like any other `point and shoot' camera, but within the housing it has five large easy buttons (Play, Menu, Flash, Focus, Delete) that handle all the underwater functions you need. It is easy enough to do it without focusing too much on the buttons - after a while you can easily work them on night dives. There is a function for color lens as well including nine settings (usually set to Standard, but the Sepia tone is handy as well as all the standard colors. I had fun setting it to sepia while night diving with nurse sharks).

Reviews.Title: Good point and shoot for underwater
Reviews.Author: El Tombo "NNPS9107"

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_moQW7G6ACI5VW9currentClick) { return cv_moQW7G6ACI5VW9currentClick(); } } } Length:: 0:16 MinsUpgraded to this for my "snorkeling" camera after having OK luck with one of those "waterproof to 30ft" types (olympus' older version). The earlier camera worked fine for about a year and a half and 2 trips to Hawaii before it started flaking out. But I was never comfortable with it in the water. I always babied it and never took it deeper than 5ft or so, even though I like to go much deeper than that.This camera I feel comfortable taking it as deep as I can go, and I'm sure scuba folks would be OK to use this to the rated depth. Also this one floats if you drop it, so one less thing to worry over.As far as picture and video quality go, as I check head-to-head with my older pix and videos, I think the older camera probably beats this one slightly, though as you'd probably expect neither is ready for National Geographic. Both have trouble in low light, though if you're snorkeling on top on a sunny day, that might not be too big a deal.I'm adding a short video clip from Hawaii snorkeling. Also I'll put a few more pics on the gallery.EDIT--> Just took a look at the uploaded video. Just wanted to say the "waviness" in the video is some kind of amazon processing artifact, not in the original. Also, they seem to have bumped down the resolution quite a bit. Not really a good demonstration of actual video.Pros:-Smallest and cheapest "with case" underwater camera you're likely to find anywhere.-Camera floats.Cons:-Picture and video quality is probably just one notch above your cell phone.Bottom line, here's the underwater options as I see it:1) Buy this camera for around $300-400. I'd go with this if you need some depth or plan to go underwater a LOT. Especially salt water.2) Buy something like the Panasonic DMC-TS3 for $200-300. I'd buy this for occasional pool shots and bad weather photography. Maybe a few snorkeling trips in calm water. But expect to buy another in a few years.3) Go for a real upgrade and get something like the Canon G12 with a Canon-built housing (WP-DC34) for around $600 (wow).Frankly, if the G12 option had been this cheap 9 months ago, I probably would have gone there. The G12 is a fine camera for outside the water too. Though the G12 with case would be much more bulky than the other 2 options for "casual" shooting.

Reviews.Title: Scuba fun
Reviews.Author: browntiger
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  Easy to use.  Big keys for gloved fingers. I have used this camera on 4 different dives and the pictures are awesome in all of them.

Reviews.Title: Read the directions
Reviews.Author: Schilling3D
Reviews.Content: My camera worked flawlessly and took awesome pictures at 92 ft. Very easy to use with gloved hands. Very easy to read the buttons underwater. You people who wrote reviews about over or under exposed pictures: READ THE DIRECTIONS. For those of you whose camera flooded: READ THE DIRECTIONS.

Reviews.Title: Great Quality for your money!
Reviews.Author: Sharon
Reviews.Content: This is such a great camera in  and out of the water.  It's extremely user friendly the lack of cluttered buttoms makes it easy to operate underwater.  The housing is plain and simple, keep an eye on the o-ring and the camera is fine.The photo quality is simply amazing.  I love this camera!  Video quality is also awesome.

Reviews.Title: not easy to use at all
Reviews.Author: FEI TAN KUNG
Reviews.Content: battery die after  80 plus  pictures...company did sent us a new replacement, but lost the opportunity for some great pictures in Palau.

Reviews.Title: Good camera, disastrous housing
Reviews.Author: Clint
Reviews.Content: The title says it...we had some pretty good luck with this camera (although the "Easy" settings weren't great, the white balance override made for some good pictures) but we used it for less than a dozen dives before the flash flooded due to an O-Ring issue.Literally the next dive the camera flooded due to an O-Ring issue.  The way the way the O-Rings are set in the camera, it's truly just a matter of time.  You'd think a camera designed specifically to work underwater would have a better and more reliable sealing device.By comparison, we have had IkeLite cases for our Canon cameras for years (200+ dives) and have not had a single problem.  So it might be user error, but the margin for error is a LOT smaller with the Sea Life.Again, if the housings protected better, I'd have great things to say.  For now though, I'm sitting on several hundred dollars of ruined equipment that worked for less than one full dive trip.

Reviews.Title: UnderWater camera
Reviews.Author: todd white
Reviews.Content: This camera Works just great. Just what i ordered and quick shipping. Good job.  The battery seems to be holding a charge without issue. I get more than a month on a charge.  The camera takes great pictures and great videos.  I only use it for underwater, so cannot comment on how the pics are except for under water.

Reviews.Title: Great underwater camera
Reviews.Author: Basketc8s
Reviews.Content: Very happy with this product.  Took it snorkeling and scuba diving.  It picked up the whale songs when scuba diving and using video feature.  When looking at the prints did need to use the red filter to get more color.

Reviews.Title: LOVE IT!
Reviews.Author: Islandgirl19
Reviews.Content: Great camera! Bought it for my hubby for his birthday before our trip to St. Thomas. The camera is fantastic in the water and out of the water! A must buy for anyone wanting a nice underwater camera!!!

Reviews.Title: This is a horrible camera.
Reviews.Author: MTB
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera before I made a recent trip to the Galapagos Islands.  I didn't want to buy underwater film cameras for snorkeling around the islands.  I wanted good, digital photos on one camera.  I bought the Sealife camera and noticed that the only mechanism providing protection from water is a small and ineffective O-ring wedged in the middle of a plastic case.  This is basically an overpriced cheap digital camera sold in a cheap "waterproof" case.  On my first snorkeling expedition it took awful photos.  The case obscured the lens, and the color was monochrome.  On my second snorkeling, the camera's O-ring did not maintain a seal and water seeped in the case and ruined the camera.  If it wasn't for the memory card I bought separately for the camera, I would have no photos.  With the card I got 20 below average quality underwater photos.  The snorkeling was amazing, but this lousy product failed me and I couldn't photograph the wonderful sea life.  This camera is a Sea FAILURE, and I do not recommend buying this product.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing picture quality
Reviews.Author: Adrian King
Reviews.Content: Pretty disappointed in this product. The underwater case and the camera itself are nicely compact and simple to use but the digital picture quality is absolutely awful. Usually VERY overexposed, very poor white balance and very weak flash. Most of my pictures (recent trip to Hawai'i) came out pretty lousy. I used to use a Sony point and shoot with an accessory underwater case. It was a little more awkward to use but the picture quality was far superior. I'm going back to the Sony, the Sealife product was very disappointing.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Robin M. Stonehouse
Reviews.Content: I have done plenty of research on underwater cameras and housing compartments. Sealife always ranks up there. I have now purchased this camera twice and both times, it stopped working after the first time of using them. Very disappointed. Easy to use.

ProductInfo.Features:
12 megapixel, image resolution, 5X optical, 3" LCD underwater/land camera in rubber armored housing
Wide-spread controls. No Button Clusters. 5 large menu keys, Oversized shutter button and zooming lever for easy camera control, even with gloves on.
Easy Set-up mode ¿ Easy 1-2-3 graphic on screen guide ¿takes the guess work out of setting up the camera for great pictures
4 Underwater Modes for sharp, colorful underwater pictures.
Includes Sea mode with 4 New built-in color correction filters, Ext Flash Auto mode, Ext Flash Manual mode and Snorkel mode.
ProductInfo.Name: Sealife 12 Megapixel 5X Optical Zoom and 3-Inch LCD screen Underwater/Land Camera
